PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

A Revalidation of the initial Process Hazard Analysis was conducted in June 2004, which generated mitigation measures (recommendations) to improve safety at the Los Angeles Cold Storage facility located at 400 South Central Avenue in Los Angeles, California.  The Los Angeles Cold Storage safety committee is planning to complete several items, including the recommendations, over the next year, as a continual effort to provide a safe work environment for their employees.  These changes include the following items:

1. Continue to train all employees in Process Safety Management and the facility Safety Plan/Programs.

2.	Continue to have employee involvement in Safety Plan Development.

3.	Continue employee involvement through safety team participation.

4.	Continue internal and external safety audits/inspections and implement changes as needed.

ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES

Los Angeles Cold Storage senior management is not only committed to offer superior service, but also maintain a safety and environmental program to promote a safe environment for all its employees and the surrounding communities. Los Angeles Cold Storage maintains a safety committee whose members are the designated emergency coordinators for the facility. Los Angeles Cold Storage has an Emergency Response Plan (Plan) in effect, which is detailed in the Program Element Binder Section 12. document maintained at the facility.  The Plan provides the response organization and notification procedures, evacuation routes, ammonia health hazards, and mitigation procedures, which will be implemented to respond effectively to emergency situations that may arise at the facility.  This Plan is reviewed and updated at least once per year.  This Plan will be reviewed and updated to ensure compliance with the PSM and RMP regulations, as well as to incorporate any facility changes.

STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCE

The Los Angeles Cold Storage facility is located at 400 South Central Avenue in Los Angeles, California.  Highway 101 is approximately one mile to the north and to the east of the facility, the Santa Monica Freeway (Interstate 10) is 1.2 miles to the south, and the Harbor freeway (Highway 110) is 1.8 miles to the west.  The facility is located in downtown Los Angeles, and the area immediately surrounding the facility is residential and commercial.  The system and the facility were constructed in accordance with the most recently adopted Uniform Fire and Mechanical Codes.

Anhydrous ammonia is used as a refrigerant in the Los Angeles Cold Storage facility refrigeration system. The liquid is circulated as needed to the evaporators where heat is absorbed and removed from the medium. The anhydrous ammonia refrigeration system is a closed loop industrial refrigeration system. The ammonia is not used or mi

xed in any manner with other chemical processes.

ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS

The Los Angeles Cold Storage facility was designed and constructed in accordance with the 1994 Uniform Mechanical Code which specifically outlines requirements for the safe operation of ammonia refrigeration systems.  

Los Angeles Cold Storage ammonia refrigeration system has many safety features.  Much of the safety associated with the system is inherent in the policies and procedures that govern the operation of the systems.  For example, the facility operates in accordance with OSHA¿s Process Safety Management regulation.

FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

An investigation into the Los Angeles Cold Storage facility accident history during the Process Hazard Analysis Revalidation (June 16, 2004), revealed that there have been no reportable ammonia related accidents, incidents or releases at the facility over the past five years (June 1999 - June 2004).

EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

The Los Angeles Cold Storage facility has adopted emergency response procedures and policies.  The Emergency Response Plan (Plan) is detailed in Program Element Binder Section 12, which is maintained at the facility.  This Plan was designed to meet the following objectives:

1.)  To save lives.
2.)  To minimize and avoid injuries.
3.)  To protect the environment.
4.)  To minimize property damage.

The Plan provides the response organization and notification procedures, evacuation routes, ammonia health hazards, and mitigation procedures, which will be implemented to respond effectively to emergency situations that may arise at the facility.  This Plan is reviewed and updated at least once per year.  This Plan will be reviewed and updated to ensure compliance with the PSM and RMP regulations, as well as to incorporate facility changes due to the renovation of the facility.  The Plan is distributed to new hires who are required to read and sign a certification page.  F
